action: I want to be able to review all important operation history records within the system
reason: To quickly respond to internal fraud detection, security incident investigations, and compliance audit requirements
acceptance_criteria: Audit logs are only viewable by authenticated users.
Only users with the Administrator role hold audit log viewing permissions.
Return 403 Forbidden if a user without permissions attempts to access.
All important operations (login, registration, update, deletion, approval, etc.) must be subject to audit logging.
The operating User ID must be recorded in the log.
The target resource ID of the operation must be recorded in the log.
The operation type (CREATE / UPDATE / DELETE / LOGIN, etc.) must be recorded in the log.
The operation date and time (in UTC) must be recorded in the log.
The source IP address of the operation must be recorded in the log.
User-Agent information must be recorded in the log.
Values before and after the change (diff) must be saved in the log.
Sensitive values such as passwords must be masked.
Logs must be saved in tamper-evident storage (e.g., WORM storage).
Log deletion cannot be executed by normal users.
The log retention period is configurable (e.g., 5 years).
Audit logs must be searchable.
Searching by date range is possible.
Searching by User ID is possible.
Searching by operation type is possible.
Searching by target resource ID is possible.
Search results must support pagination.
Return a maximum of 100 records per response.
Log output (CSV export) is possible.
Export operations must also be recorded in the audit log.
Rate limiting is applied to the log retrieval API.
Parameterized queries are used as SQL injection countermeasures.
XSS countermeasures are applied to the log display screen.
Log data is retrieved via HTTPS communication.
Target response time for the log retrieval API is within 1 second.
Log saving processes are handled via an asynchronous queue.
Retry processing is performed if log saving fails.
Log writing is handled as an external transaction process to avoid obstructing business logic.
The log table is isolated from the main business database.
Audit logs can be output in a format compatible with external SIEM integration.
Fraudulent operation detection and alerting for administrators must exist.
Notifications occur for abnormal patterns, such as deletions exceeding a specific count.
The log viewing screen has a sorting function.
The log viewing screen can maintain its filter state.
Internal system structures are not returned during API errors.
The audit log specification itself must be subject to change history management.
--- Additional Security & Traceability Enhancements ---
Each log entry must include a digital signature to verify integrity and prevent post-hoc tampering.
Implement a 'Correlation ID' to trace a single user request across multiple distributed services in the logs.
Access to the audit logs themselves (who viewed which logs) must be recorded as a 'meta-audit log'.
